summary: so like here's the thing with taylor not wanting to play songs that people don’t know as well for the b stage acoustic each...
body:
so like here’s the thing with taylor not wanting to play songs that people don’t know as well for the b stage acoustic each night.

Yes, maybe the average taylor swift fan won’t know the fearless bonus tracks or songs like starlight, but you better believe that all the swifties out there will know every single word. They will be screaming the lyrics whist simultaneously crying. To them, it would mean more than you could possibly imagine.

tags: pop is actually a very good grooming tools
calling rebellion what's just conformity to patriarchal standards
title: In defense of Taylor Swift
body:
Or how it is difficult to exist outside the Virgin Mary / Whore dichotomy.

Until recently I wasn’t really familiar with Taylor Swift’s music, but as she grew popular I inevitably listened to a few of her songs. It’s not my type of music, but it’s not bad at all, in terms of composition and writing. 

What I think is interesting the way this artist is treated by the media, the audience and her colleagues is that if her music isn’t revolutionary, her personality, as an artist, is quite unusual for an American female pop singer. 

I remember when I was a teen and Britney Spears was the era’s megastar, how she was extremely sexualized, while being asked by her management to say she was a virgin, and that she wanted to wait to get married to have sex. While singing “I’m a slave for you” in a fake baby voice - her real singing voice is probably much deeper as you can hear in this song- she was pretending to have no sex life of her own, which was of course, a lie. Sex was for sale, not for her, it was a marketing tool.

Many female pop singers fell into that. Those who started as teenagers where all pushed into the “good girl gone bad” narrative, from Lindsay Lohan to Miley Cyrus, to Ariana Grande. All were asked to fake innocence while being sexualized, and probably while being around people who preyed on young girls. And at some point, they “break free” ( 1, 2, 3, 4 and so on) and become what they were always supposed to be: sexy and on display. After that, some sometimes spiral down into depression and/or addiction, and get into a sexualization dead-end that is just uncomfortable to watch (1, 2).

Singers who started as adults didn’t have a fake innocence phase, but for popular American singers, it seems impossible to exist without being heavily sexualized. It’s always presented as something liberating (just let me liberate you eh eh eh) and anyone who dares questioning it gets branded as a prude, or worse, a slut-shamer. With a heavy dose of liberal feminism, female singers are encouraged to objectify themselves while presenting it at some form of empowerment. Examples are countless (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7…)

Truth is, it’s the price to pay if you want to sing about love, sex and desire. And if you do, don’t sing about your desire, sing about how great it is to be desired, how much you aim to please. If you don’t want to be sexualized, then you need to sing about asking Jesus to take the wheel, or something.

And then you have Taylor Swift, who sings about her complicated love life, have never pretended to be a virgin while wearing cute dresses and polka dots. She would have been fine if she had remained a country singer, or if she had become more of an indie / folk singer. Thing is, Taylor Swift fills stadiums and wins pop awards. 

She started as a teenager, but has never tried to be anything else that her own age. She grew up to become a beautiful woman and could have been very easily and successfully turned into a sex object, with the proper grooming. And she gets criticized mainly for that. Since she sings about her love life, then her love for cute clothes, cats and baking must be fake. It’s like people can’t reconcile the fact a woman can have many lovers without being a caricatural seductress dressed in BDSM attire.

I wonder why it’s more controversial to be Taylor Swift than to be any one of the 100 sexy clones we’ve been fed with these last 25 years. Actually I know. it’s just good old misogyny. She can’t sing about her lovers if she doesn’t pay the price of objectification, especially if she sings from her perspective and not only about how she wants to be good for someone else so he can come and get it, you know, when HE wants.

I’ve seen that recently she’s been trying to get closer to the “sexy” cliché. Well, she shouldn’t. It seems, sadly that she’s soon going to get through, at almost 30, her “good girl gone bad” phase. If someone’s giving her that kind of advice, she should let them go. There are other ways to reinvent oneself as an artist.  I don’t think singers should be “role models”, because usually, it’s only asked of female singers to be some kind of youth leaders. But it would be sad to see this narrative prevail again.
